title: Collaborative Efforts to change Science Publishing
segmentation: Hi good afternoon.
Thank you very much for for having me in this panel.
I think this is a really great opportunity to talk with all of you about these things that I think all of us have been dreaming about.
But now they're really really coming to the four and I'd like to talk about.
Three topics, first, uh bit about entities.
Then a bit about hypothesis in evidence and Lastly some words on different types of collaboration.
So first entity.
I mean, I think you need to talk about entities at a semantic web conference.
Little use case, we have a Journal called Febs Letters, Federation of European Biochemical Societies and since April of.
2009 they have started on F.
Where they have implemented what is called the structured digital abstract concept.
I don't know if you've heard of this.
That's something that is very prevalent as a concept in biology and bioinformatics.
Essentially, it's saying that you want to have an XML machine readable XML summary.
Now that should probably say machine readable RDF summary, but they didn't want to scare anybody away.
We didn't know what RDF meant, so of pertinent facts.
I'll come back to the to the issue of what is it?
Act later, but but basically the idea is that together with an article in this Journal, you would provide proteins that are discussed in this article.
Protein, protein, interactions and the way that these produce proteins interactions have been found in the form of methods.
These are bits of knowledge that are stored in a database.
The Mint database in Rome.
And what we've done starting in April 2000.
2008 sorry, it's been going on for a year.
Ask the authors to provide these XML pertinent facts.
And then we started at a very low tech end, so the authors supplied Excel spreadsheets with these facts.
And currently we have 117 articles that contain such a structured digital abstract.

The nice thing is that this ended up creating a very nice gold standard because we had these manually articulate an annotated articles, so all the binary formations were jumping all over it, and in fact now at the Bio Creative Challenge 2009.
This is the corpus that's going to be used to see if they can improve the automatic extraction of protein.
Teen interactions

I'll just briefly show you what it looks like, so following every article is such a small summary and as you see it looks already very very RDF E for the simple reason that people aren't actually using this as RDF, we're not exporting it as RDF, but if anybody is interested in using it in that way, we're happy to do it.
You can probably just turn it into it at in the blink of an eye yourself, so these are these.
These interactions.
Is the mint ID links to the?
Mint.
Database and the protein ID links to the Uniprot database.
So fairly straightforward.
The reason I'm telling you this as an introduction.
Are involved in the Occam project, which is an integrated project that is funded by the European Union.
It's a very, very interesting and large project to support and enable the use of globally unique identifiers for entities on the web.

I won't go into it in a great detail because we only have a little bit of time, but the parable cat is here and I think some other people have the option project as well, and tonight there will be a demo of one of the organ plugins so please come see that Ockham has an infrastructure and entity base and a number.
Extensions and in our project we've been working on an extension to Ms Word.
One of the thing for for identifying proteins, which I'll show you in a second.
So currently we're focused focusing on proteins and protein protein interactions, but we want to tackle author identifiers next, which I think it will be an interesting challenge everybody.
Every publisher everybody who has a fourth profile.
Everybody who makes RFID's tags comes up with a new way to identify a person.
And I think it's a great challenge and a useful thing to do to say.
People are really the same people.
So, just briefly to show.
Are you the entity editor in Microsoft Word?
It's a very simple word plugin.
This is also downloadable from the Welcome Home page.
If you want to play with it.
It doesn't work on Mac.
I have to add it so Windows only.
Unfortunately at the moment you can run this in Word.
You can identify entities.
Currently identifying proteins where.
Working on the interact.
Now click through it briefly sorry.
Actually, you saw there that that it went to Ockham, picked up the Akamai dies and it renders them as an index at the beginning of your documents.
So you can imagine that this can help the author in a semi automated way identify entities in their documents.
So that's what I wanted to say about entities.
I want to move on a little bit if we're talking about ways of represent.
Signs publishing I think it's.

Important to realize that science occurs in language, this is a paragraph from a random science article on cell biology an I'm not sure how many of you are biologists and can follow this, but you probably all recognize that this is a typical scientific article and this is how currently the bulk of scientific information is translated an I think it's very important to realize that that.
If science is done in language.
We should use linguistics.
There's a whole field dedicated to figuring out how humans parse language.
What are the important elements in language?
What type of things can you pull out of language, and how do you do it?
What I'm showing here is a very simple identification.
You can look for instance at the verb tense and how it changes.
In fact, in biology it's quite remarkable.
Within a sentence, you can have two or three times the verb tense change.
Nobody notices it because it's very innate to how we.
How we produce and process text.
We use these verb tenses to indicate different rounds of experience.
In fact, we use certain markers.
We use connectives, we use direct appeals to the audience.
Sometimes we use things like these data show and we all know what's going on.
So this is just a very small slide that says a bit about.
Let's look in detail at how science communicates how science is communicated currently.
So that we're sure that we don't lose anything if we do.
Want to go to new farms?
So.
Just a little model here that that that has come.
This is this was my.
This is the work I'm doing it at University so I have a dual affiliation sponsored by the Dutch Scientific Federation anveo.
I think you can say.
That this holds true for a lot of a lot of elements of science.
That science is really conducted in in two realms, or you can't read the bottom.
But it says data around OK.
So you have the conceptual realm, and then in the conceptual realm you have some statement.
Then you refer in experimental Sciences.
This is this case you refer to your experiment.
Refer to your data and that that's how you prove your point.

In general in biology that the endpoint over argumentation is some data representation, and then you take it back into the conceptual realm and kind of looping from the realm of concepts into the realm of experiments and back again is how generally the argumentation is.
Formed and I think you can model this as as hypothesis are created on the base.
List of existing facts and on the basis of experimental evidence.
So this model of hypothesis in evidence and the ability to represent an article as a.
Election of hypothesis.
And evidence was something that, as I went to conferences and talk to people, I saw that it was.
It was really a very popular model and some people have been working on this for a long time.
And some people are coming to it from all kinds of different directions.
So I think the liquid pub concept.
There certainly was this element other.
Work done by Tim Clark.
Work done.
Xerox in identifying hypotheses automatically work done at dairy for connects and salt, so identifying sentences.
Linked by rhetorical ways and a group at the Knowledge Media Institute have been working on this for a long time.
Used to be called playmakers now.

So here, so there are all these groups that are working with this concept of hypothesis, evidence in relationships and about a month ago we had a meeting in Amsterdam to see if we could get all these groups around the table and just this.
Gus and see what Happ.
And it was, I think, a very, very interesting meeting we had.
Oh sorry, I want to include the Oxford.
I don't have a picture of Oxford, but David Shelton's work?
We all got.
Together it was a very great grassroots kind of thing, and we say.
So what?
What are things we want to do?
No matter how you know, we were very interested in pursuing this in kind of a kind of a larger.
Larger collaboration, but currently already we can start aligning discourse ontologies.
We can start perhaps looking at new formats for conference proceedings.
Why do we just use this simple narrative format?
Surely we can add some structure.
We're also looking at structured but Oracle abstract.
Neuroscience.
But we're very much interested in building on this effort.
Ann, and welcome anybody to the table who is interested in representing scientific articles by this kind of concept.
That kind of brings me to.
Last topic, which is collaborate.
It's it's been very interesting to me to see that really talking with people about changing modes of of scientific communication makes them very susceptible to changing the way they communicate.

I agree with my retail, we're not as far yet as as your son who is talking, chatting with his friends on Facebook to get tips but but I do think that people are quite interested in this type of open collaboration, so I want to mention two efforts I've been involved in.
Briefly, one with the elders of your.
One challenge Ascentia Lee.
What we did last year was say to the community at large.
Anybody who's interested this happened to be limited to the life Sciences, but anybody who's interested in talking with us and suggesting tools to improve the way that.
Science is communicated essentially.
Please submit an abstract and we got in six weeks time.
It was quite nice we go.
71 submissions, ten of those were so.
Opted to go on to the next round and then given access to a large corpus of of of your content.
I think a lot of times people don't have access to the vast corpus.
Is that commercial publishers have an?
I think it's very interesting as a way to collaborate that you know we give the data you work on the data we all see what comes out kinda thing.
And then we actually have a special issue.
Journal web semantics in the pipeline that describes the 10 semifinalists.
And then in April.
Four finally
We were selected from, which finally two winners were chosen.
The first prize went to the reflecting and Heidelberg.
It's a very semantic tool.
It identifies entities and gives you a bit of.

Information on an entity and the second prize went to dairy to the corral tulan I think see how much you can talk about this much more much better than I can, but it's quite an exciting tool that essentially turns this vast data.
Goes into triples.
The last project I want to mention is a plan we have for.
We really liked the fact that we got all these very, very different inputs from people.
So we got people with semantic bag, web, computational linguistics.
But also, you know, random random scientists have to speak who are interested in changing the way they communicate.
So we're interested in expanding this Ann, and we're now planning a conference with with roughly very similar.
Scope to the challenge.
We have these three areas that we'd like to invite explicitly, but we're very open, so semantic web, computational linguistics, and publishing, and information science.
Also getting more input from social Sciences are very interested in the processes of how does science change when you change groups?
How you communicate.
And I think it's it's kind of thrilling.
'cause for this conference, what we're thinking is as soon as the website is up.
Essentially, the conference starts right?
I mean, why not have a virtual community be a conference?
So as soon as the website is up, you log on.
You say something about yourself and your interests, and you can start communicating with people who are also interested in participating.

You can start, for instance, proposing workshops we'd also like have to have some kind of Democratic vote of what talks would you like to see of all the of all the submissions, and we're hoping that that using some of these two oh techniques people can kind of cluster into groups and identify their interests, so I think that's it.
Watch this space and I'll hand over to Andre.
Thank you.
